abstract: A story considered too dark for Broadway in its time is too much of a patchwork in ours.
lead_paragraph: What a shame that the 1962 musical “I Can Get It for You Wholesale,” a critique of vulture capitalism disguised as a rag trade comedy, is now best known as the Broadway show that gave Barbra Streisand her start at 19. No matter how good she was — and the recording of her big number, “Miss Marmelstein,” overflows with stupendous, youthful invention — hers was only a small, comic role in a much darker story by the novelist Jerome Weidman; her song a bauble in a fascinating and multifaceted score by Harold Rome.
headline: ‘I Can Get It for You Wholesale’ Review: Rag Trade Revival, Recut for Today
keywords: Theater;Theater (Off Broadway);Classic Stage Company;I Can Get It for You Wholesale (Play);Weidman, Jerome;Rome, Harold;Weidman, John;Cullman, Trip;Fontana, Santino;Jones, Rebecca Naomi;Kuhn, Judy;Lester, Julia (2000- )

abstract: An exhibition at the Getty Museum reveals the Egyptian Book of the Dead, long relegated to a dark vault, in the light of day.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-19th century, a British antiquarian named Sir Thomas Phillipps announced his intention of owning one copy of every book in the world. A professed “vello-maniac,” Mr. Phillipps, a quarrelsome baronet, bought manuscripts indiscriminately from booksellers with whom he engaged in ceaseless battle. Soon there was hardly room in his moldering Cotswolds mansion for his second wife, Elizabeth, who eventually moved to a boardinghouse in Torquay, an English working-class seaside resort. By the time Mr. Phillipps died in 1872, he had amassed an unparalleled collection of 60,000 documents and 50,000 printed books.
headline: Now Showing, an Ancient Spell Book for the Dead
keywords: Archaeology and Anthropology;Egyptian Civilization;Getty, J Paul, Museum;Egypt;your-feed-science

abstract: Israel advances on Gaza City.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military advanced deeper into Gaza yesterday, approaching Gaza City from three directions. Israel has provided only limited details about the invasion, but photos and videos verified by The New York Times, as well as satellite imagery, showed troops and armored vehicles closing in on the city, Gaza’s largest, from the north, east and south. Israel has also continued to batter the territory with airstrikes.
headline: Tuesday Briefing

abstract: In “The Race to Be Myself,” the Olympic runner tells the full story of her gender-based discrimination and dehumanization by the global athletics world.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, the 18-year-old South African track star Caster Semenya arrived in Berlin to run in the 800-meter event in that year’s World Championships. But before she was allowed to participate in the race — which she won — the International Association of Athletics Federations subjected her to multiple rounds of nonconsensual “gender confirmation tests” in response to public speculation that she was unfairly competing in the women’s category because of rumors she was male. A panel of German doctors tried to perform a transvaginal ultrasound on her, with only an English-German translator present (English is Semenya’s second language). She refused.
headline: Caster Semenya: ‘I’m Still a Woman’
keywords: Running;Books and Literature;Olympic Games (2012);Gender;Semenya, Caster

abstract: A writer spends eight days exploring the world of British farmhouse cheeses, from London to the West Country, where a good Cheddar rules the day.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny October afternoon in the London neighborhood of Bermondsey, a cool breeze surprised me with the winy smell of apples. It brought on a sudden sharp craving for a nice chunk of Cheddar, the fruit and the cheese together being a favorite after-school snack when I was growing up in Connecticut. This was an appropriate prompt, too, since I was on my way to a very privileged lesson in British farmhouse cheeses at the beginning of an eight-day, cheese-themed trip to London and Somerset run by the specialty tour company Cheese Journeys.
headline: The Big Cheese (Tour)

abstract: How a disappearing act became the default ending to so much human interaction.
lead_paragraph: Horror movies are always a good reflection of the culture that created them. In the 1980s, as if in response to the repressive evangelical movement gaining hold in American politics, grotesque body horror (“The Fly,” “Society”) became a defining genre, along with a succession of gratuitously violent slasher films in which hormonal teenagers meet gruesome ends, usually just beyond the sphere of adult supervision (“The Burning,” “Friday the 13th,” “Sleepaway Camp”). In the 1990s, horror films grew more excessive, with bigger budgets, but some added irony and self-awareness to speak to a generation of jaded young viewers who had seen it all: The potential victims in Wes Craven’s “Scream” (1996) display a deep knowledge of horror film tropes.
headline: Why Can’t We Give Up the Ghosting?
keywords: Movies;Ghosts;Talk to Me (Movie);Dating and Relationships

abstract: When my neighborhood changed around me, I decided to change it.
lead_paragraph: I’ve become a real kvetch. I have lived in the same neighborhood, in Brooklyn, for the better part of the past decade, spending the last five years in a hand-me-down apartment from a friend. One day I recognized where I lived; the next, I didn’t. Overnight, gaggles of 20-somethings began to roam the streets, presumably in search of eyebrows, which none of them seemed to have. Rent became obscene. I’d find myself the only Black person standing on the corner, waiting for the light to change. New high-rises as elegant as Lego blocks appeared on what seemed like every other street. Passive-aggressive notes from new residents started popping up in my lobby. One night, I came home to a can of alcoholic seltzer on top of my mailbox.
headline: The Joy of Picking Up Other People’s Trash
keywords: New York City;Brooklyn (NYC);Urban Areas;Waste Materials and Disposal

abstract: Loving our guns to death.
lead_paragraph: In Anthony Mann’s 1950 western “Winchester ’73,” a rare and much-desired Winchester rifle brings misery and death to the unlucky souls who manage to bring it into their possession. In the West as brought to you by Mann — and his star, a troubled and morally ambiguous Jimmy Stewart — the gun isn’t a symbol of freedom as much as it is a curse, destined to ruin everyone who covets its power.
headline: America’s Rifle Fetish Is Destroying Its Sense of Freedom

abstract: He was a brilliant performer, but his honesty will be his greatest legacy.
lead_paragraph: A long time ago I lay awake for hours, terrified that they would be my last ones on earth. I had committed myself to quitting cocaine, which was my second addiction, the first being years of amphetamines. I was devoting myself to cleaning up and getting healthy. But then a friend called who I had routinely done coke with and who always had a supply of the drug. Earlier on that black night, I’d careened backward into the familiar land of white lines on a mirror and a heart racing way too fast. It was pounding so hard, so fast, so loud, I was certain it and I couldn’t survive.
headline: Matthew Perry and the Loneliness of Addiction
keywords: Loneliness;Drug Abuse and Traffic;Alcohol Abuse;Addiction (Psychology);Perry, Matthew
